description: A now-peaceful theocracy that has benefited greatly from their warlike Chobesh neighbors' collapse.
A conglomerate of various island groups that sends privateers to raid other nations' ships.
A formerly-powerful kingdom that lost it all after a century at war with its neighbors, and lies in ruin.
The unified nation of elves; these long-lived people have little interest in short-term power grabs.
A desert nation that has built up strength through alliances and trade; they compete with Geuhwae.
A formidable naval armada that controls a puppet kingdom while frequently invading the Tip nations.
An alliance of a church and a kingdom; they routinely crusade against Xuruk's nearby undead.
A magically-formidable utopia that thrives deep in the dangerous Bowl using their arcane barriers.
A potent nation where the sizable aristocratic class manipulates the lower classes away from revolt.
A massive empire that formed from the merger of various rival states; it is an economic titan.
A nomadic group that moves between dodging monsters near Hueztotli and raiding Geuhwae.
A grouping of similar Orc tribes that, unable to easily raid Ikkutiq, have settled down to learn magic.
A group of Kobold clans that tunnel under undead palaces to raid them of their riches.
A hive-state of insect-people whose Queen's word is law; they seem to be allied with Khanghal.
An attempt at a Goblin nation, modeled after Ugexiir, that wants to be a dominant force in the Bowl.
A rebel state that has split off of Otekai, and has been embroiled in that civil war for centuries.
An honor-driven nation that refuses to admit surrender or sign a treaty in their war against Notsurashi.
A land that has driven off many Goblin invasions, and watches with curiosity as Mobyuld forms.
A grim nation that has the misfortune of being located closest to the undead hordes of Xuruk.
An organized civilization of amphibious tentacled humanoids that trades heavily with the Deep Lands.
A nation that has somehow survived despite being based in a jungle with terrifyingly-strong monsters.
A group of nations across a wide area that speak a common language, but don't share a government.
A small island nation that has nonetheless intimidated its neighbors into respecting its territory.
A fallen empire of necromancers overthrown by their undead minions; the walking dead own this land.
Monsters that aren't part of a civilization are generally called beasts, regardless of their intelligence.
